subject: Law
title: The Twelve Tables of Rome
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Twelve Tables of Rome.

hook.text: In 450 BCE, Roman plebeians demanded the laws be written down. Until then, only patricians knew the rules.

buildup.text: The Twelve Tables were Rome's first written legal code, publicly displayed so all citizens could know the law.

discovery.text: They covered debt, property, family, inheritance, and legal procedure. Simple, blunt, and practical.

twist.text: Harsh by modern standards: a debtor could be enslaved, and false witnesses faced execution.

climax.text: Their real power was transparency. Written law meant accountabilityâ€”no more secret rules benefiting the elite.

punchline.text: Writing laws down was revolutionary. Knowing the rules changed everything.

quiz.question: Why were the Twelve Tables significant?
options: They made Roman law publicly accessible
